Moments ago, we learned that Governor Kate Brown announced an extension of Oregon’s statewide school closure to a total of six weeks, through April 28, and issued an executive order for Oregon’s public schools. This is difficult news for us all.

As we navigate this new terrain, the district team and I are continuing to develop resources and make plans, and will keep you apprised how we will support our students, staff and families in light of the extended school closure announced to all of us moments ago. Please visit our LOSD website for resources.

We understand and appreciate that you have many questions. We are working on understanding the guidance from the governor and how it impacts LOSD specifically. We will be working diligently on answering your questions and providing direction as soon as possible. Thank you for your patience and support as we work through this dynamic and complex time.

She spent time with the class answering impromptu questions, and the kids had very insightful questions for her. At the end of our day, Senator Rob Wagner took time out of his day to answer more questions from the entire group. It was indeed a fun-filled day of learning!

post_text: Congratulations to Dr. Kurt Schultz, Principal of Lakeridge Junior High, who recently completed his Doctor of Education degree with an emphasis on Learning and Leading through the University of Portland's Graduate School of Education. Dr. Schultz has worked the past three years on his research around the connection between teacher professional development and student learning. The District has been proud to support his efforts as a lifelong learner and is pleased to add another administrator with a doctoral degree to its ranks. Dr. Schultz defended his dissertation titled "The Relationship of the Teaching, Empowering, Leading and Learning (TELL) Survey Responses to Student Smarter Balanced Assessment (SBA) in Math and English: Teacher Professional Development and Student Achievement" (https://pilotscholars.up.edu/etd/56/) in March and celebrated graduation with his family and the rest of his doctoral cohort this May.

Our students will have the opportunity to fuel their learning in our new makerspaces. Students will get to choose from nine different technology systems and work collaboratively through a series of benchmarks to complete their projects.

post_text: Forest Hills Elementary recently wrapped up their Kids Heart Challenge for the year (formerly Jump Rope for Heart). Kids Heart Challenge is a nationwide event in schools that supports the American Heart Association. This was their most successful year yet. Students raised $15,377.90 and 176 students participated. Both are school records! Forest Hills also received a grant to purchase PE equipment for the school. As a reward, the top two participating classes would get to silly string the PE teacher, Melinda McDonald. "Not the highest amount of money raised but the most participants per class. Wouldn't you know it we have a tie for second place - guess that means I'll get it three times instead of two," said Ms. McDonald. Tammi Leach's class had 70% participation and Kristin Peterson and Theresa Cumpston tied with 68% participation. #LOSDProud

A January 2018 study looked at the positive effect of integrative STEM programs on elementary students’ attitudes towards science. The study found that 83.7% of the fourth-grade students who were taught with STEM programs expressed positive opinions about science, indicating that they saw science as useful (60%) and that they were able to use imagination and creativity during experiments (73.3%). Of the fourth-grade students who were taught without STEM programs, they found that 80.5% of the students reported negative feelings about science, stating that it was too hard because of the many exercises and homework (82.2%) and boring due to regular textbook reading (46.3%).
This study sheds light on what we at LOSD are looking to provide for our students: Understanding, appreciation, and love for learning. We value our STEM curriculum, and so do our students.

If approved, what would the Local Option Levy cost?
The 2019 Local Option Levy would maintain existing funding while levying homeowners an additional $0.25 per $1,000 of assessed value for a total cost of $1.64 per $1,000. An owner of a home with a median assessed value of $450,000 would pay an additional cost of approximately $9.33 per month. An estimated total levy of $738 per year would be assessed on the median homeowner if the levy passes. If the proposed levy does not pass, the total tax assessment would decrease when the current levy expires in 2020. If the proposed levy does not pass, downsizing decisions would need to be made totaling more than $10 million.

• Cuts to programs like science, technology, engineering, math, and the arts
• Elimination of vocational/technical and other hands-on learning programs
• Reduction in extracurricular programs, field trips, and athletics
• Loss of academic and mental health counseling supports

If the proposed levy does not pass, the total tax assessment would decrease when the current levy expires.

Karen Stewart, secretary at Westridge, explained, "Our Special Services team put together a sensory center where students identified smells. Our PE teacher brought in vendors from Mathnasium, Mad Science, Lakeridge Robotics, and others and had them set up all around the gym. Our music teacher showed students how filling glasses with different amounts of water created different notes. It was a great evening!" #LOSDProud

Wondering what is new about this year's Learning Levy?

The 2019 levy continues funding to preserve more than 80 teachers, licensed staff, and support staff, but it also makes new and important investments in our local schools, like:

Mental Health Support
3 new elementary mental health and social-emotional learning counselors
4 new secondary mental health/social-emotional learning counselors

STEM/Innovation
6 new elementary STEM/innovation teachers; one for each elementary school makerspace
2 new secondary STEM/Innovation teachers; to build out computer science offerings

Reading/PE
3 new elementary reading support/learning specialists
1.5 new PE support staff for elementary schools

Safety
1 additional school resource officer

Find out more: www.losdschools.org/domain/1805
